desc: prove there exist a_i and a_j such that n|(a_i+i)-(a_j+j)
solution:
\begin{soln}
  We first solve part (i) and then part (ii).
  \begin{enumerate}[(i)]
    \item   FTSOC assume that there does not exist any $a_i$ and $a_j$ 
  such that $a_i+i \equiv a_j+j\pmod{n}$.

  Therefore $\left\{ a_i+i \right\}_{i=1}^{n}$ is the CRS modulo
  $n$. Therefore, summing the elements of the two sets,
  of the CRS and the set $\left\{ a_i+i \right\}_{i=1}^{n}$,
  we get that $\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_i\equiv 0\pmod{n}$. This implies
  that $n\mid \frac{n}{2}\cdot (n+1)$ which gives a
  contradiction as $n$ is even.
  \item No, the result is not true for odd $n$. Consider the
    sequence $\left\{ a_i \right\}_{i=1}^{n}$ where $a_i=i$.

      Then if $a_i+i\equiv a_j+j\pmod{n}$ for distinct $i$ and
      $j$, then $n\mid 2(i-j)$ which implies $n\mid i-j$ as
      $\gcd(n,2)=1$. Moreover, note that as $i\neq j$,
      $n\le |i-j|\le n-1$ which gives a contradiction.

      Thus all $(a_i+i)$ are distinct modulo $n$.
  \end{enumerate}
\end{soln}
